newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dollar seen edging lower vs yen in Asia.
newsitem.headline: Dollar seen edging lower vs yen in Asia.

text.p: The dollar is likely to drift lower against the yen in Asia on Tuesday amid lingering worries about Japan's ballooning trade surplus, dealers said.

The U.S. currency, however, is expected to remain in a relatively narrow range versus the mark after European Union (EU) finance ministers reached a compromise deal on Monday on limiting budget deficits after the launch of Europe's single currency.
"With uncertainties about the EU stability pact out of the way, the market's focus is likely to shift back to U.S.-Japan trade," said a trust bank trader.
Dealers are focusing on Japan's May customs-cleared trade data due out on Wednesday and U.S. April international trade data on Thursday.
Economists polled by Reuters forecast, on average, that Japan's May trade surplus rose to 548.5 billion yen, from a surplus of 229 billion yen a year earlier.
Forecasts ranged from 400 billion yen to 760 billion yen.
"Over the last few days, the market has confirmed that dollar/yen is quite top-heavy at 115 yen. Hence, we may test the downside ahead of the trade data and G7 summit," said a city bank trader.
Offers from Japanese exporters above 115.00 yen were heavy, dealers said.
Meanwhile, Japanese institutional investors so far have not shown much dollar-buying interest, though they might come in near 112 yen, a trust bank trader said.
The mark is also likely to remain under downward pressure against the Japanese currency, as some Japanese exporters are falling behind schedule in selling marks for the yen, dealers said.
Dollar/yen ended Monday's New York trade lower after fears about Japan's trade surplus took hold.
The greenback also ended down against the German currency in New York on Monday as profit-taking set in after the EU finance ministers reached a compromise deal on the stability pact.
The dollar rallied versus the mark last week in anticipation of an accord on the stability pact.
The deal raised the odds that the single European currency would be launched as planned in January 1999, possibly with a easier entry criteria, dealers said.
